title: How to Make a Fudge Oreo With Chocolate Sauce

steps.headline: Open up each Oreo.
steps.description:
To do this without breaking the cookie, grip it gently on both sides and twist one side to one direction. At the same time, twist the other in the opposite direction. If this doesn't work, use a butter knife to gently wedge in between the two cookie halves and push them apart. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/20\/Make-a-Fudge-Oreo-With-Chocolate-Sauce-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Fudge-Oreo-With-Chocolate-Sauce-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/2\/20\/Make-a-Fudge-Oreo-With-Chocolate-Sauce-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/aid1760186-v4-728px-Make-a-Fudge-Oreo-With-Chocolate-Sauce-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

steps.headline: Scrape the Oreo filling off each cookie half.
steps.description: This is optional but helps to prevent the cookie from being overly sweet; for some, the fudge flavor might not go well with the Oreo filling.

steps.headline: Add fudge sauce to a cookie half per cookie double.
steps.description: Add with care and do not overfill.

steps.headline: Press each of the cookies back together again.
steps.description: Wipe away any oozing fudge sauce using your finger or a butter knife. They should look like normal Oreo cookies when done.

steps.headline: Arrange on a sheet of wax paper on a freezer-proof tray or plate.
Place the fudge-filled Oreos into the freezer.
Let them sit for up to about 10-15 minutes.
Remove from the freezer.
steps.description: When you take them out, they should feel cold and the fudge should be frozen or just about frozen. If you take it out and it still isn't frozen, then put them back in for 5-8 minutes.

steps.headline: Arrange the fudge-filled, chilled Oreo cookies onto a plate.

text:
Preparing the Oreo Cookie Open up each Oreo. To do this without breaking the cookie, grip it gently on both sides and twist one side to one direction. At the same time, twist the other in the opposite direction. If this doesn't work, use a butter knife to gently wedge in between the two cookie halves and push them apart. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/20\/Make-a-Fudge-Oreo-With-Chocolate-Sauce-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Fudge-Oreo-With-Chocolate-Sauce-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/2\/20\/Make-a-Fudge-Oreo-With-Chocolate-Sauce-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/aid1760186-v4-728px-Make-a-Fudge-Oreo-With-Chocolate-Sauce-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Scrape the Oreo filling off each cookie half. This is optional but helps to prevent the cookie from being overly sweet; for some, the fudge flavor might not go well with the Oreo filling. Adding the Fudge Sauce Add fudge sauce to a cookie half per cookie double. Add with care and do not overfill. Press each of the cookies back together again. Wipe away any oozing fudge sauce using your finger or a butter knife. They should look like normal Oreo cookies when done. Arrange on a sheet of wax paper on a freezer-proof tray or plate. Freezing and Serving the Cookies Place the fudge-filled Oreos into the freezer. Let them sit for up to about 10-15 minutes. Remove from the freezer. When you take them out, they should feel cold and the fudge should be frozen or just about frozen. If you take it out and it still isn't frozen, then put them back in for 5-8 minutes. Arrange the fudge-filled, chilled Oreo cookies onto a plate. Sit down, and enjoy!
